data.name: Binary Range Extraction
data.description:
# Preface
This kata is something of an extension of a previous kata: `Range of Integers in an unsorted string` (https://www.codewars.com/kata/5b6b67a5ecd0979e5b00000e). 
It is recommended that you attempt that kata first, though this kata is by no-means unapproachable for complete newcomers. 

# Task
Your task is to "unshuffle" a range of numbers (represented in binary) given two arguments:
 - `string` (the shuffled range of numbers)
 - `n` (the length of the range)
Your function should return the lowest number of the range.

## Example 1
`unshuffle('111101110', 3)` should return `5`.

This is because `111101110` can be split into 3 binary representations of numbers, and these numbers form a range of length 3, i.e:
```
`111101110`
= 111 - 101 - 110
= 7 - 5 - 6
```

## Example 2
`unshuffle('10011010101110111001000111101', 10)` should return 1, because
```
'11110001001110110101101011100' 
= 111 - 1000 - 1001 - 1 - 101 - 1010 - 110 - 10 - 11 - 100
= 7 - 8 - 9 - 1 - 5 - 10 - 6 - 2 - 3 - 4
```
which is the range of numbers from 1 to 10.

# Caveats
- Every number in the range will be between 1 and 127.
- No binary representations will have leading zeroes (i.e. `0110` is not a valid binary representation of `6`).
- Not all binary representations in the range will have the same number of digits.
- `n` (the length of the range) will always be between 3 and 30.
